title: 2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics

last_post.content:
If you're even passingly interested in #dataviz / etc, take a few to compare these two offerings:

(1) The NYT's "2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics" https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/12/28/us/2022-year-in-graphics.html

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Even allowing for the fact that two projects are different in key ways — institutional capacity and context foremost among them — what strikes me is how flat, conventional, and superficially decorative the Tableau offerings are.

From the mid-'90s, when dataviz became more (yes) a pop phenomenon, it's struggled with how deeply its aesthetics are defined by the software tools designers relied on. They should have struggled *against* that, imo. But doing so would require a deeper understanding of the field's evolution over the last century than the obsessive recitation of names like Playfair and Minard (and, more recently, Nightingale and Dubois). The fixation on those historical figures is a classic bourgie move: using "classical" figures to signal tradition and legitimacy. (Datavizzies are way overdue for a new year's resolution to move on from that classic-rock stuff.)

I can be bitterly critical of the NYT, but its commitment to experimenting with journalistic form and content around dataviz is unparalleled. The fact that one institution could trot out its own work over just one year and *blow away* a more inwardly oriented dataviz roster says a lot.

It's time to unbundle science. I put in a lot of work writing blog posts. This last one (https://xcorr.net/2023/01/01/2022-in-review-neuroai-comes-of-age/) was 100+ hours in the making.

I could put in a few extra hours, reformat and submit to a preprint server to get citations. But it feels silly: lock up the research behind a pdf that's not mobile accessible, remove the convenient placement of the links for a bibliography, strip all the screenshots from the papers I link to... maybe I'd even need to change the voice to a mimic serious formal science and I don't want that.

So I'm experimental with unbundling science by making some of the artifacts citable. I released the figure I generated for this blog post on figshare, with a citable DOI. Let me know if you think this is useful. https://figshare.com/articles/figure/Typology_of_neuroAI/21818403

title: The tragedy of the commons is a false and dangerous myth | Aeon Essays

last_post.content:
The tragedy of the commons is a pernicious myth.

The demise of the commons of Britain and Europe wasn't the result of misuse by commoners, but enclosing by the landowners. The original hypothetical was made up for storytelling purposes, and the term was popularized by an ecologist with anti-immigrant and racist views.

Here is my recommended reading for heading into 2023:

https://aeon.co/essays/the-tragedy-of-the-commons-is-a-false-and-dangerous-myth

title: How Twitter misleads us about how many people have left — and what to do about it

last_post.content:
Who do so many people seem unaware of the mass exodus from Twitter?

Social media feeds are engines for distorting our social understanding. But we can push back against the algorithm, with a simple automated out-of-office message on Twitter (how-to included).

This post explains the science of social influence that allows Twitter to maintain an illusion of a full room, how to change that, & why we need industry-independent science for our digital environments.

title: Your Face Belongs to Us by Kashmir Hill: 9780593448564 | PenguinRandomHouse.com: Books

last_post.content: My book on facial recognition technology comes out on September 19! Over the last two years, I tracked down the tech's early pioneers, found the people fighting against its worst impulses, and dove into the history of Clearview AI, the start-up that first drew me into the topic with a radical person-finding app that giants in the field, including Google and Facebook, had deemed taboo. It feels real now because there's a release date and a preorder button: https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/691288/your-face-belongs-to-us-by-kashmir-hill/

TikTok's algorithm is like the formula for Coca Cola: widely believed to be the secret sauce behind the product's success, but in fact quite ordinary. In both cases, the actual reasons people are hooked has much more to do with human behavior than technology. My post on the @knightcolumbia blog, part of my project on Algorithmic Amplification and Society: https://knightcolumbia.org/blog/tiktoks-secret-sauce

title: Here’s why electric vehicles need EV-specific tires

last_post.content:
An idea, I never considered. EVs need different tires than ICE cars because

1. EVs are heavier due to batteries.

2. Tires need to be quieter because EVs have less engine noise to drown out their sound.

3. EVs accelerate faster requiring more traction.

title: Long Out of Math, an AI Programmer Cracks a Pure Math Problem | Quanta Magazine

last_post.content:
Some progress on the #FranklConjecture!

Justin Gilmer used some information theoretic arguments to establish the first constant lower bound for the fraction of sets in a #UnionClosed family that contain the same element. Initially 1%, now 38% but it looks like some new ideas are required to get to the 50% of the conjecture.

Quanta article: https://www.quantamagazine.org/long-out-of-math-an-ai-programmer-cracks-a-pure-math-problem-20230103/

Gilmer’s paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09055

The U.S. Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) published a roadmap today for research on information integrity:
https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/Roadmap-Information-Integrity-RD-2022.pdf

They outline four priority areas: 1) modeling & analyzing info ecosystems; 2) investigating safeguards (e.g. media literacy) to support healthier engagement with information; 3) envisioning technical approaches to support information integrity; 4) developing/evaluating strategies for addressing manipulative information campaigns.

I am a little nervous about this, but...

Hi, I've just moved over to hcommons.social, so here's an #introduction. I work (and make things) at the nexus of digital culture, politics and technology. I'm Prof of Media at Coventry University, UK, where I direct the Centre for Postdigital Cultures. I research non-liberal & non-humanist forms of collaboration and knowledge commons, as well as questions of class, elitism & digital capitalism. I’ve been involved for a while in creating ‘norm-critical’ collaborative research contexts. In 1999 I started an online journal Culture Machine http://www.culturemachine.net/. In 2006 I co-founded the open access publishing house Open Humanities Press. OHP was then a founder member of the Radical Open Access Collective http://radicaloa.disruptivemedia.org.uk/. My books include A Stubborn Fury: How Writing Works In Elitist Britain (OHP, 2021) http://www.openhumanitiespress.org/books/titles/a-stubborn-fury/, Pirate Philosophy (MIT Press, 2016) https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262034401/pirate-philosophy/, and The Uberfication of the University (Minnesota UP, 2016) https://manifold.umn.edu/projects/the-uberfication-of-the-university.

@michael_nielsen Btw, I consider any type of axiomatic characterization in mathematics as a form of discovery fiction.

For example, Shannon entropy was characterized by Faddeev as the only continuous function from probability distributions to real numbers that satisfies a very natural chain rule.

This is a simple way to motivate the entropy. The well-known formula with a logarithm then pops out of it by itself.

I first learned about this from a nice paper by Leinster:
http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.06961

It's time to unbundle science. I put in a lot of work writing blog posts. This last one (https://xcorr.net/2023/01/01/2022-in-review-neuroai-comes-of-age/) was 100+ hours in the making.

I could put in a few extra hours, reformat and submit to a preprint server to get citations. So I'm experimental with unbundling science by making some of the artifacts citable. I released the figure I generated for this blog post on figshare, with a citable DOI. Let me know if you think this is useful. https://figshare.com/articles/figure/Typology_of_neuroAI/21818403

4) I tried to write something like this just using clientside javascript for eg. a bookmarklet, but the CORS rules prevented me from making the fetch to the OP server. I believe a browser extension would be able to overcome that problem, and it also looks like the search API doesn't require login (which seems bad actually) and so it might not even need to have you approve it with eg. OAuth or something like that. I have only written one extremely simple browser extension before, but this is ultimately extremely simple, basically this (and then refresh the page):

fetch(<other_instance>/api/<context_endpoint>
).then( (response) => {
response.json().descendants
.forEach( (status) => {
fetch(<search_api>/<status.url>);
}
});

title: Why do economists so dislike "conditional independence"?

last_post.content: Interesting post by Scott Cunningham on how conditional independence goes against rationality (people choosing the treatment based on expected benefits) and that's why economists don't like this assumption: https://causalinf.substack.com/p/why-do-economists-so-dislike-conditional Perhaps a corollary might be that selection on observables then becomes more plausible when the "treatment" is not something you choose based on a rational calculation but instead is something like a feeling or a personality trait or some aspect of your environment.

While ChatGPT is all the rage these days, as you may know it doesn't optimize for accuracy, but rather something like plausability.

I would thus like to highlight an alternative that only answers based on scientific papers, and does so while referencing all the sources:

https://elicit.org

To me, this is pretty awesome! Let's encourage this type of projects that promote accuracy and transparency of its sources!

title: Facebook Wanted Out of Politics. It Was Messier Than Anyone Expected.

last_post.content:
There are two pieces of news in this one:

https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-politics-controls-zuckerberg-meta-11672929976?mod=tech_lead_pos2
 
1.     In late 2021, with zero fanfare, Facebook began changing newsfeed worldwide to exclude comments and reshares in how it promotes politics, societal and health-related content.

2.     This wasn’t enough for FB’s leadership and board. Late in 2021, they asked Facebook to move forward with zero-weighting ALL civic content in newsfeed. Facebook wanted out of politics.
